title: POLITICO Playbook: Behind the scenes on Trump’s Ukraine pressure campaign
text:
POLITICO Playbook: Behind the scenes on Trump’s Ukraine pressure campaign Presented by

"For months this spring and summer, Ukraine’s newly elected president, Volodymyr Zelensky, tried to deflect pressure from President Trump and his allies to pursue investigations into former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.," wrote New York Times' Ken Vogel. | Alex Wong/Getty Images

DRIVING THE DAY

EIGHT TIMES, via WSJ’s Alan Cullison, Rebecca Ballhaus and Dustin Volz: “President Trump in a July phone call repeatedly pressured the president of Ukraine to investigate Democratic presidential candidate Joe Biden ’s son, urging Volodymyr Zelensky about eight times to work with Rudy Giuliani, his personal lawyer, on a probe, according to people familiar with the matter.

“‘He told him that he should work with [Mr. Giuliani] on Biden, and that people in Washington wanted to know’ whether allegations were true or not, one of the people said. Mr. Trump didn’t mention a provision of foreign aid to Ukraine on the call, said this person, who didn’t believe Mr. Trump offered the Ukrainian president any quid-pro-quo for his cooperation on an investigation.” WSJ

-- NYT’S KEN VOGEL: “Behind the Whistle-Blower Case, a Long-Held Trump Grudge Toward Ukraine”: “For months this spring and summer, Ukraine’s newly elected president, Volodymyr Zelensky, tried to deflect pressure from President Trump and his allies to pursue investigations into former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., Mr. Biden’s son and other Trump rivals.

“The pressure was so relentless that Mr. Zelensky dispatched one of his closest aides to open a line of communication with Rudolph W. Giuliani, one of Mr. Trump’s personal lawyers. Mr. Giuliani was the loudest voice among those demanding that Ukraine look at Mr. Biden’s dealings with the country when he was vice president at the same time his younger son, Hunter Biden, was doing business there.

“Over breakfast in early July at the Trump International Hotel, Mr. Zelensky’s aide asked the State Department’s envoy to Ukraine for help connecting to Mr. Giuliani. Several days later, the aide discussed with Mr. Giuliani by phone the prospective investigations as well as something the Ukrainians wanted: a White House meeting between Mr. Zelensky and Mr. Trump.

“But if Mr. Zelensky’s goal was to reduce the pressure to pursue the investigations and win more support from the White House — not least for Ukraine’s fight against Russia — he would be disappointed.” NYT

-- WAPO’S ASHLEY PARKER: “Ukraine, if you’re listening . . .: How Trump tries to quell controversies by saying the quiet part out loud”

THE BIDEN CONUNDRUM -- WAPO’S MATT VISER: “Scrutiny over Trump’s Ukraine scandal may also complicate Biden’s campaign”: “Biden faced two dueling realities: The president he is hoping to defeat next year — and who he describes as morally unfit for office — is under scrutiny for behavior some view as treasonous. But the story is inextricably linked to Biden’s son, pushing one of the topics that Biden is least comfortable discussing into the spotlight.

“The challenge of taking advantage of this political moment without becoming ensnared was evident by how Biden responded to the news Friday afternoon. First, he reacted defensively in an exchange with reporters in Iowa. Then later, in a formal statement from his campaign, he forcefully denounced Trump’s actions.”

BIDEN’S STATEMENT: "If these reports are true, then there is truly no bottom to President Trump’s willingness to abuse his power and abase our country. This behavior is particularly abhorrent because it exploits the foreign policy of our country and undermines our national security for political purposes.

“It means that he used the power and resources of the United States to pressure a sovereign nation—a partner that is still under direct assault from Russia—pushing Ukraine to subvert the rule of law in the express hope of extracting a political favor.”

TO WIT … PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP THIS A.M. -- (@realDonaldTrump) at 8:31 a.m.: “The Fake News Media and their partner, the Democrat Party, want to stay as far away as possible from the Joe Biden demand that the Ukrainian Government fire a prosecutor who was investigating his son, or they won’t get a very large amount of U.S. money, so they fabricate a.....

“....story about me and a perfectly fine and routine conversation I had with the new President of the Ukraine. Nothing was said that was in any way wrong, but Biden’s demand, on the other hand, was a complete and total disaster. The Fake News knows this but doesn’t want to report!”

Good Saturday morning. CASH UPDATE … THE NRSC raised $3.7 million in August.

A message from Softbank: America is where the world's innovation happens, and SoftBank is helping that innovation come to life. Here in the U.S., we're investing in people, companies and transformational technology that is reshaping the future and improving people's lives. Learn more about SoftBank's investment in the U.S. and watch our new video at politico.com/sponsor-content/softbank.

THIS HAS TO BE A FIRST -- SEAN SPICER launched a “campaign” for “Dancing with the Stars” votes. His new ad

SPEAKER NANCY PELOSI SPEAKS TO NPR …

-- ON THE WHISTLEBLOWER COMPLAINT: "This case has a national security piece to it that is very alarming. It is very alarming because the inspector general is appointed by President Trump." Pelosi told NPR information must be sent to congressional intel committees. “Right now they are breaking the law” since they aren’t providing the report.

-- ON INDICTING A SITTING PRESIDENT: “I do think that we will have to pass some laws that will have clarity for future presidents. President should be indicted if he's committed a wrongdoing any while in office should any president. There's is nothing anyplace that says the president should not be indicted, that is something cooked up by the president’s lawyers. That’s what that is.”

-- ON USING A NATIONAL EMERGENCY TO FUND THE BORDER WALL: “The president should not be able to interpret the National Security Act as something that gives him free reign to do anything he wants by his personal declaration that something is an emergency.” Full NPR story

NYT EDITORIAL BOARD … RARE MCCONNELL PRAISE: “As ‘Moscow Mitch’ Rings in His Ears, McConnell Backs Election Security: Even if it took a taunt to do it, he approved $250 million for voting protections.”: “We come to praise Mitch McConnell, not to bury him. On Thursday, the Senate Appropriations Committee unanimously approved a bipartisan spending package containing $250 million to help states safeguard voting systems. Among the co-sponsors was the majority leader, Mr. McConnell, who, in a floor speech before the committee’s vote, declared himself ‘proud’ to support the measure.

“To say this was a welcome surprise would be an understatement. Mr. McConnell has spent the past year-plus blocking multiple bipartisan proposals for election security. This despite warnings from the intelligence community and others that American elections remain vulnerable to outside interference. In his testimony before Congress on Russia’s meddling in the 2016 presidential race, Robert Mueller, the former special counsel, stressed that Russia was still ‘doing it as we sit here’ even as other foreign actors were poised to do the same.”

POLITICO Playbook newsletter Sign up today to receive the #1-rated newsletter in politics Email Sign Up By signing up you agree to receive email newsletters or alerts from POLITICO. You can unsubscribe at any time.

U.S. TROOPS TO SAUDIA ARABIA -- “US to send troops to Saudi Arabia, hold off on striking Iran,” by AP’s Lolita C. Baldor and Robert Burns: “The Pentagon on Friday announced it will deploy additional U.S. troops and missile defense equipment to Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, as President Donald Trump has at least for now put off any immediate military strike on Iran in response to the attack on the Saudi oil industry.

“Defense Secretary Mark Esper told Pentagon reporters this is a first step to beef up security and he would not rule out additional moves down the road. Gen. Joseph Dunford, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said more details about the deployment will be determined in the coming days, but it would not involve thousands of U.S. troops.

“Other officials said the U.S. deployment would likely be in the hundreds and the defensive equipment heading to the Middle East would probably include Patriot missile batteries and possibly enhanced radars.” AP

IT’S OFFICIAL … KENNEDY JUMPS IN -- “Kennedy plays an unfamiliar role in Senate primary clash — insurgent,” by Stephanie Murray and James Arkin in Boston: “The first days of Joe Kennedy’s Senate primary campaign offer a glimpse at the coalition he hopes to assemble in his challenge to Sen. Ed Markey, a blockbuster contest that could reorder Massachusetts’ congressional delegation.

“After launching with a breakfast Saturday in East Boston, where the Kennedy family traces back to a neighborhood populated by Irish immigrants in the mid- to late-1800s, he’ll embark on a three-day statewide tour that begins Saturday. The roughly 15-stop trip is largely focused on immigration, affordable housing and the opioid crisis. He’ll meet with LGBTQ asylum seekers and refugees in Worcester, and talk about climate change and union jobs in New Bedford. In Boston, he’ll tour an affordable housing development.

“It’s a strategy that focuses less on winning over activists and establishment leaders, and more on turning out new voters — particularly immigrants and people of color — who typically vote at lower rates than white voters do. It’s a model that worked spectacularly here for Democratic Rep. Ayanna Pressley in her insurgent 2018 House campaign against another fixture of the state political establishment, then-Rep. Michael Capuano.” POLITICO

A message from Softbank: We're on track to invest $50 billion in U.S. companies by the end of 2020. Learn more about SoftBank's investment in the U.S. at politico.com/sponsor-content/softbank.

2020 WATCH …

-- THE ‘COACHELLA OF THE CAUCUSES’ -- AP: “Steak, beer and politics: 2020 Democrats descend on Iowa,” by Alexandra Jaffe and Thomas Beaumont in Des Moines, Iowa: “This year, 11,000 people are expected to join in addition to 19 presidential candidates. Attendees can listen to bands, munch on 10,500 steaks or get food from food trucks, a vegan grill or a craft beer tent.

“There are even camping grounds, where supporters of former Texas Rep. Beto O’Rourke spent Friday night. The festival vibe has some Iowa activists calling the steak fry the ‘Coachella of the Caucuses,’ referring to the weekend-long music festival in California. Polk County Democratic Party Chairman Sean Bagniewski said the event purposely has a ‘modern twist.’”

-- “Next one out? Booker memo warns he may not be in 2020 race 'much longer'” by NBC News’ Alex Seitz-Wald: “Sen. Cory Booker must raise nearly $2 million in the next 10 days or the presidential candidate has no "legitimate long-term path forward," according to a memo to staff from the campaign manager obtained by NBC News.” NBC News

-- “Democratic Opponents Search for a Plan Against Elizabeth Warren,” by WSJ’s Ken Thomas and Eliza Collins

-- “Buttigieg fights to lock down Iowa LGBTQ vote,” by Elena Schneider in Cedar Rapids, Iowa: “Friday’s LGBTQ Presidential Forum had the feeling of a home game for Pete Buttigieg, who was introduced as ‘a member of our community’ to a rousing standing ovation. But that enthusiasm for Buttigieg has not guaranteed him a lock on this voting bloc in Iowa.” POLITICO

-- WAPO’S PAUL KANE: “Running up the score in House races could deliver White House to Democrats”

TRUMP’S SATURDAY -- The president has nothing on his public schedule.



PLAYBOOK READS

PHOTO DU JOUR: President Donald Trump and first lady Melania Trump welcome Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison and his wife Jenny Morrison for a State Dinner on Friday. | Evan Vucci/AP Photo

ABOUT LAST NIGHT … “Trump brushes off political controversy to wine and dine Australia at state dinner,” by WaPo’s Sonia Rao and Roxanne Roberts: “Clear skies overhead, Trump and Morrison toasted each other and their countries' alliance while standing behind a lectern in the White House Rose Garden. ‘Americans and Australians hold within our hearts a great love of family, a profound allegiance to our fellow citizens, a deep respect of law and liberty, and a determination to protect our independence at any cost,’ Trump said to a crowd of nearly 180 attendees. Morrison echoed the sentiment, raising a glass ‘to 100 years of mateship, and to 100 more.’” WaPo

-- “Melania Trump’s Say-Nothing State Dinner Dress,” by NYT’s Vanessa Friedman: “On Friday night, as the co-host of her second state dinner since becoming first lady and thus a figurehead of the nation, as well as a symbol of her husband’s administration (whether she likes it or not; that’s the job), Melania Trump clothed herself in her now-signature aplomb and ambivalence.

“As fashion statements at major public events when you know all eyes are on you go, hers was a polite nod; a no-teeth smile, lips clamped firmly together, in sartorial form. In fact, what was most notable about it was what it did not say.” NYT

VALLEY TALK -- “Facebook CEO tries the quiet approach to soothing Washington,” by Cristiano Lima and Nancy Scola: “Mark Zuckerberg’s Washington tour this week represents a new approach to politics for him: low-key, closed-door but highly solicitous of the most important players in town. Facebook's CEO had previously addressed concerns about privacy and social media through acts of public contrition and limited engagement with Congress or the White House. Zuckerberg’s last appearance in the nation's capital was a contentious congressional hearing in April 2018.

“This time, the social media giant’s founder — clad in a suit and tie, saying nothing to reporters — spent three days engaged in quiet diplomacy with members of Congress and President Donald Trump. That included a final day of private meetings on Friday, including with lawmakers pursuing antitrust investigations of the tech industry and others drafting legislation to restrict how websites use consumer data.

“The personal touch seemed to resonate with some members, though others remained critical of the industry. While it wasn’t quite clear what Zuckerberg accomplished on the host of questions Facebook faces on issues like user privacy, anti-competitive behavior, Russian election interference and the company’s plans for a cryptocurrency, the mood music was certainly different.” POLITICO

MEDIAWATCH … NEWSMAX inked a new carriage distribution agreement with Cox, which they believe will put the conservative news organization in the homes of 3 million subscribers in California, Arizona, Nevada and Georgia.

-- “As a foreign reporter visiting the US I was stunned by Trump's press conference,” by Guardian’s Lenore Taylor

CLICKER – “The nation’s cartoonists on the week in politics,” edited by Matt Wuerker -- 18 funnies



A message from Softbank: Learn more about SoftBank's investment in the U.S. and watch our new video at politico.com/sponsor-content/softbank.

GREAT WEEKEND READS, curated by Daniel Lippman (@dlippman), filing from New York:

-- “America, the Gerontocracy,” by Tim Noah in POLITICO Magazine: “In 1982 ... the median age of a Politburo member was 71. ... The U.S. doesn’t have a Politburo, but if you calculate the median age of the president, the speaker of the House, the majority leader of the Senate, and the three Democrats leading in the presidential polls for 2020, the median age is … uh … 77.” POLITICO Mag

-- “The Lawless Frontier at the Heart of the Burning Amazon,” by Jesse Hyde in Rolling Stone: “Inside the battle for the forest’s future — and ours — as Brazilian ranchers and farmers vow to protect their way of life at any cost.” RS

-- “Constance Wu’s Hollywood Destiny,” by The New Yorker’s Jiayang Fan: “Coming late to celebrity, the star has felt the burden of representing all Asian-Americans.” New Yorker

-- “Why can’t we agree on what’s true any more?” by William Davies in The Guardian – per TheBrowser.com’s description: “Public life in the age of social media is like a play in which every member of the audience is a critic. All statements by public figures are picked apart and quickly declared to have some occult purpose. As cynicism becomes generalised, people tend to favour their own experiences and their own beliefs about how the world ‘really’ works. Our crisis of democracy proceeds from this crisis of truth. We reject ‘official’ stories about everything, and demand to witness things for ourselves.” Guardian

-- “How Many Personal Stories Must Women Share to Convince Others of Their Humanity?” by Lyz Lenz in Time: “Women have long been compelled to share their most private moments in order to convince others of their humanity. But in recent years, as we’ve peered into an uncertain future and need only pull out our phones to see highly personal warnings of the stakes, everything seems amplified. The waves of stories, put forth in tweets and speeches, testimony and essays, have felt incessant, each crashing down upon us with little chance to breathe before the next one.” Time

-- “Why Women’s Soccer Players are Worried about Their Brains,” by Mirin Fader in Bleacher Report: “The biggest stars in the world are pledging their brains. Young players are leaving the game with their destinies unfulfilled. The stories they tell spark fear and raise questions. And the science hasn’t even begun to provide answers.” Bleacher Report (hat tip: Longform.org)

-- “Who Would I Be Without Instagram?: An investigation,” by Tavi Gevinson in The Cut: “I think I am a writer and an actor and an artist. But I haven’t believed the purity of my own intentions ever since I became my own salesperson, too.” The Cut

-- “The Secret Story of Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid’s Last Tango,” by Patrick Symmes in The Daily Beast: “According to the movie version, they died side by side, guns blazing, in the crosshairs of half a Bolivian regiment. It’s a great Hollywood ending that happens to be true, mostly: they left America… then died in Bolivia. What Hollywood didn’t know is that Butch and Sundance escaped.” Daily Beast (h/t Longform.org)

-- “Edward Snowden and the Rise of Whistle-Blower Culture,” by Jill Lepore in The New Yorker: “In his memoir, he chronicles his life game by game, from Nintendo to the N.S.A.” New Yorker ... “Permanent Record” -- $18 on Amazon

-- “How Boeing’s Managerial Revolution Created the 737 Max Disaster,” by Maureen Tkacik in TNR: “There aren’t any pilots on the Boeing board, and the only engineer in the C-suites is CEO Dennis Muilenburg—and pilots and engineers were the ones who found the crash unnerving.” TNR (h/t Longreads.com)

-- “Medicaid’s Dark Secret,” by Rachel Corbettt in October’s Atlantic: “For many participants, the program that provides health care to millions of low-income Americans isn’t free. It’s a loan. And the government expects to be repaid.” The Atlantic

-- “The Fight for the Latino Vote in Florida,” by Jonathan Blitzer in The New Yorker: “Immigration, taxes, and health care matter, but a foreign-policy issue has taken center stage.” New Yorker

PLAYBOOKERS

Send tips to Eli Okun and Garrett Ross at politicoplaybook@politico.com.

SPOTTED: Ben Bernanke and Richard Clarida having lunch at Old Ebbitt Grill on Friday. … Democratic Florida Reps. Val Demmings and Brian Mast in coach on the 1:44 from DCA to Orlando. Baseball legend Johnny Damon was in first class. … The Detroit Pistons’ Blake Griffin on the patio at Le Diplomate on Friday night, drinking a glass of red wine.

SPOTTED at the state dinner Friday night with Australian PM Scott Morrison: VP Mike Pence and Karen Pence, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and Louise Linton, Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross and Hilary Geary Ross, USTR Robert Lighthizer and daughter Claire Lighthizer, U.S. Ambassador to Australia A.B. Culvahouse, Rudy Giuliani, Sen. Roy Blunt (R-Mo.) and Abby Blunt, Sen. Joe Manchin (D-W.Va.), Sen. Jim Risch (R-Idaho), House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy, Rep. Mark Meadows (R-N.C.) and Debbie Meadows …

… Education Secretary Betsy DeVos and Dick DeVos, Stephen Miller and Katie Waldman, David and Catherine Bohigian, Anthony Pratt, Lou Dobbs, C. Boyden Gray, A.G. Bill Barr and Christine Barr, John Rogers and Deborah Lehr, Greg Norman, Kellyanne Conway, Australian Ambassador Joe Hockey and Melissa Babbage, Larry and Judy Kudlow and Charlotte Mayor Vi Lyles.

TRANSITION -- Veronica Bonilla will be media director at the Aerospace Industries Association. She is currently press secretary to Rep. Norma Torres (D-Calif.) and is an Amy Klobuchar alum.

BIRTHWEEK (was Friday): Lisa Bloom … Melissa Jane Kronfeld … WaPo’s Sophia Nguyen turned 27 (hat tip: Grayson Clary)

BIRTHDAYS: Rep. Pramila Jayapal (D-Wash.) is 54 … Rep. David Trone (D-Md.) is 64 … Rep. Al Lawson (D-Fla.) is 71 … Shealah Craighead, the White House photographer … Brianna Keilar, CNN senior Washington correspondent and anchor ... Dan Turrentine (h/t Patrick Mellody) … Kiki Burger, account director at Sunshine Sachs (h/t husband Tim) ... Maggie Dougherty … NYT Executive Editor Dean Baquet is 63 ... former CIA Director James Woolsey is 78 … Melanie Steele ... former Kentucky Gov. Steve Beshear is 75 ... Ashley Tate-Gilmore is 36 ... POLITICO’s Karey Van Hall … Jessica Andrews … Reuters’ Alexandra Alper (h/t Roberta Rampton) … Anna Greenberg, managing partner at Greenberg Quinlan Rosner (h/ts Jon Haber and Teresa Vilmain) ... Cass Sunstein, professor at Harvard and an Obama WH alum …

… Samantha Power, former U.S. ambassador to the U.N. and author of “The Education of an Idealist” … Mike Walsh, chief of staff for the Department of Commerce … Brian Roehrkasse, VP of external comms at BAE Systems … Franklin Zyriek (h/t dad Don) … Andrew Mahaleris is 25 ... NBC News PR’s Dominique Cuce ... Joel Epstein … Kelly Lindner … Georgette Spanjich, VP of Plurus Strategies, is 31 (h/t Sarah Litke) … Charles Garrison ... Beacon Media’s Ian Russell ... Erin Graefe Dorton, managing director at Prime Policy Group … Zeke Turner ... Patricia Summers Edwards ... Elizabeth Wiebe … Laurel Ruza ... Monica Carmean ... Matt Thorn … Toula Vlahou ... Lydia Stuckey ... Sarah Sibley … John McKechnie ... Mike Veselik ... Soren Dorius

SUNDAY SHOWS by Matt Mackowiak, filing from Austin:

-- ABC’s “This Week”: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo … James Mattis … Cokie Roberts tribute: Sam Donaldson and George Will. Panel: Karen Travers, Donna Brazile, Mara Liasson and Karen Tumulty.

-- CBS’ “Face the Nation”: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo … John Kerry. Panel: Radhika Jones, David Sanger, Lanhee Chen and Ben Domenech.

-- “Fox News Sunday”: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo … Sen. Ben Cardin (D-M.D.). Panel: Jonah Goldberg, Susan Page, Matthew Continetti and Juan Williams … “Power Player of the Week” segment with actor Denzel Washington and 2018-2019 Boys and Girls Clubs of American National Youth of the Year Malachi Haynes.

-- NBC’s “Meet the Press”: Treausry Secretary Steven Mnuchin ... Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.) … Sen. Pat Toomey (R-Pa.). Panel: Robert Costa, former Rep. Carlos Curbelo (R-Fla.), former Rep. Donna Edwards (D-M.d.) and NBC News’ Kristen Welker.

-- CNN’s “State of the Union”: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin … Rep. Adam Schiff (D-Calif.). Panel: Rep. Ben Ray Lujan (D-N.M.), former Rep. Mia Love (R-Utah), Karen Finney and former Sen. Rick Santorum (R-Pa.).

-- Fox News’ “Sunday Morning Futures”: Sen. Lindsey Graham (R-S.C.) … Rep. Devin Nunes (R-CA) … Gen. Jack Keane (USMC, Ret.).

-- Fox News’ “MediaBuzz”: Mollie Hemingway … Philippe Reines … Beverly Hallberg … Corey Lewandowski … Emily Jashinsky … Jessica Tarlov.

-- CNN’s “Inside Politics”: Panel: Julie Pace, Seung Min Kim, Michael Bender and Sahil Kapur.

-- CNN’s “Fareed Zakaria GPS”:Panel: Martin Indyk, Anne-Marie Slaughter and Robin Wright … U.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres … Malcolm Gladwell.

-- CNN’s “Reliable Sources”: Shane Harris … Panel: Carl Bernstein, Samantha Vinograd, Philip Bump and Tara Dowdell … David Zurawik … Robin Pogrebin and Kate Kelly.

-- Univision’s “Al Punto”: Panel: Husband of migrant mother who died crossing the Rio Grande with their 1-year-old son Elmer Cordova … Univision News medical correspondent Dr. Juan Rivera … interim Venezuelan president Juan Guaidó … former Rep. Joe Walsh (R-Ill.) … Argentinean pop star Emilia.

-- C-SPAN: “The Communicators”: MoffettNathanson Research co-founder & senior research analyst Craig Moffett, questioned by The Washington Post’s Cat Zakrzewski … “Newsmakers”: Rep. Rob Bishop (R-Utah), questioned by CQ Roll Call’s Ben Hulac and The Hill’s Miranda Green … “Q&A”: Heritage Foundation president Kay Coles James.

-- MSNBC’s “Kasie DC”: Sen. Ben Cardin (D-Md.) … Rep. Ro Khanna (D-Calif.) … Rep. Harley Rouda (D-Calif.) … Rep. Vicente Gonzalez (D-Texas) … Cecile Richards … SEIU president Mary Kay Henry … former U.S. Amb. to Yemen Gerald Feierstein … former U.S. Amb. to the U.N. and Meridian International CEO Stuart Holliday … Ken Dilanian … Jeff Mason … Susan Del Percio … Lanhee Chen … Matt Gorman … Christine Quinn (substitute anchor: MSNBC’s Ayman Mohyeldin).

-- Washington Times’ “Mack on Politics” weekly politics podcast with Matt Mackowiak (download on iTunes, Google Play, Spotify or Stitcher or listen at MackOnPoliticsPodcast.com : Author and Juniper Research Group founder and CEO Chris Jacobs.
